chapter_2_The_java_util_function_Package

Class Recipe_2_4_Functions

  • java.lang.Object
    • chapter_2_The_java_util_function_Package.Recipe_2_4_Functions

  • public class Recipe_2_4_Functions
extends java.lang.Object

    (2.3.) Recipe_2_4_Functions


    1. TO DO

      - implement Function interface to transform an input parameter into an output parameter

    2. HOW

      - provide a lambda expression that implements R apply(T t) method

    3. EQ.

      • mappingStringsToTheirLengths() - mapping strings to their lengths

    The methods in the Function interface: 
     
 default <V> Function<T,V> andThen(Function<? super R, ? extends V> after)
 default     R             apply(T t)
 default <V> Function<T,V> compose(Function<? super R, ? extends V> before)
 default <T> Function<T,T> identity()
    The most common usage of Function is as an argument to the Stream.map(Function) method.

    The complete list of primitive variations for both the input and the output generic types: 
     
 IntFunction           R      apply         (int value)
 DoubleFunction        R      apply         (double value)
 LongFunction          R      apply         (long value)
 ToIntFunction         int    applyAsInt    (T value)       => used by IntStream    Stream.mapToInt(ToIntFunction)
 ToDoubleFunction      double applyAsDouble (T value)       => used by DoubleStream Stream.mapToDouble(ToDoubleFunction)
 ToLongFunction        long   applyAsLong   (T value)       => used by LongStream   Stream.mapToLong(ToLongFunction)
 DoubleToIntFunction   int    applyAsInt    (double value)
 DoubleToLongFunction  long   applyLong     (double value)
 IntToDoubleFunction   double applyAsDouble (int value)
 IntToLongFunction     long   applyAsLong   (int value)
 LongToDoubleFunction  double applyAsDouble (Long value)
 LongToIntFunction     int    applyAsInt    (Long value)
 BiFunction            void   accept        (T t, U u)
 ToIntBiFunction       int    applyAsInt    (T t, U u)
 ToDoubleBiFunction    double applyAsDouble (T t, U u)
 ToLongBiFunction      long   applyAsLong   (T t, U u)
    If the argument and the return type, the java.util.function package defines UnaryOperator. There are also interfaces for primitives values - IntUnaryOperator, DoubleUnaryOperator and LongUnaryOperator interfaces.
    An example of UnaryOperator is StringBuilder.reverse() method because both the input type and the output type are strings.

    The BiFunction is defined for two generic input types and one generic output type, all of which are assumed to be different.
    If all three are the same, the package includes the BinaryOperator interface.
    An example of BinaryOperator is Math.max(int, int), because both inputs and outputs are either int, double, float or long.
    The interface also defines the interfaces IntBinaryOperator, DoubleBinaryOperator and LongBinaryOperator for these situations.

    Other uses of Function:
    • Map.computeIfAbsent(Object, Function) - if the specified key doesn't have a value, use the provided Function to compute one and add it to the Map
    • Comparator.comparing(Function) - the method generates a Comparator that sorts a collection by the key generated from the given Function
    • Comparator.thenComparing(Comparator) - an instance method, also used in sorting, that adds an additional sorting mechanism if the collection has equal values by the first sort

    Functions are also used extensively in the Collectors utility class for grouping and downstream collectors.
    See Also:
    Recipe 3.3. for more on BinaryOperator uses in the standard library, Recipe 4.3. for the identity method, Recipe 4.6. for using functions as downstream collectors, Recipe 5.8. for andThen and compose methods uses

      • mappingStringsToTheirLengths

        protected static void mappingStringsToTheirLengths()
        ◊◊◊ Mapping Strings to their Lengths ◊◊◊ 
             List<String> strings = Arrays.asList("string", "word", "something", "random", "stuffy", "stuff");

     // Using anonymous inner class
     String collectedStrings = strings.stream().map(new Function<String, String>() {
         @Override
         public String apply(String s) {
            return String.format("%10s has length %2s", s, s.length());
         }
     }).collect(Collectors.joining("\n"));

     // Result:
     //    string has length  6
     //      word has length  4
     // something has length  9
     //    random has length  6
     //    stuffy has length  6
     //     stuff has length  5
